subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
The Middle East is plunging deeper into chaos as
  clashes continue between rival Palestinian groups in Gaza. Today, as Israel
  launched explosive air strikes, the harshest Palestinian infighting took
  place outside Gaza
City’s pro-Hamas
  Islamic University. Allen Pizzey will report and David Martin will have more
  about the United States’
  role in this new explosion of violence – it is backing and training
  fighters from Hamas’ rival group, Fatah.
 
A battle of a different kind is going on in the United States.
  A group of gun owners has a message for New York City
  mayor Mike Bloomberg: don’t pick on Virginia. They’re hosting what
  they’ve dubbed a “Bloomberg Gun Giveaway,” a publicity
  stunt that’s already garnered national attention. Sharyn Alfonsi will
  report.
 
There’s an important update on the
  investigative story our chief investigative reporter Armen Keteyian broke
  earlier this week. He reported that FEMA trailers that house displaced
  hurricane Katrina survivors are unleashing toxic fumes on their residents.
  Now, action is being taken. For more updates, check out our investigative
  blog, Primary
  Source, at CBSNews.com.
 
You may have heard about the pair of humpback whales
  that are stranded in the Port
   of Sacramento, more
  than 90 miles from the ocean. Marine scientists’ most recent attempt to
  lure them out to sea hasn’t been successful. Sandra Hughes will tell
  you about their Plan B.
 
Finally, the story our viewers chose this week for
  Assignment America – and to call it a success story of the American
  Dream would be an understatement. We will introduce to you a brain surgeon know
  by his patients as Dr. Q. But once upon a time he was crossing the southern
  border of the United
    States and laboring here as an illegal
  immigrant. Steve Hartman will share the story.
 
Also during the broadcast tonight, we’ll give
  you a special preview of our retrospective tonight of Walter Cronkite’s
  life and career as he turns – can you believe it – 90 years old.
  It was a pleasure working on this program about such talented and
  inspirational journalist. I hope you’ll join us.
 
Have a great weekend,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
